title: The Unexamined Life
author: Plato
content: The unexamined life is not worth living.

title: Knowledge and Ignorance
author: Plato
content: I know that I know nothing.

title: Excellence as Habit
author: Aristotle
content: We are what we repeatedly do. Excellence, then, is not an act, but a habit.

title: Self-Reliance
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
content: Trust thyself: every heart vibrates to that iron string.

title: Natural Living
author: Henry David Thoreau
content: In wildness is the preservation of the world.

title: Strength Through Suffering
author: Friedrich Nietzsche
content: What does not kill me makes me stronger.

title: Essays on Life
author: Michel de Montaigne
content: Nothing is so firmly believed as what we least know.

title: Deliberate Living
author: Henry David Thoreau
content: I went to the woods to live deliberately, to front only the essential facts of life.

title: Individual Genius
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
content: To be yourself in a world that is constantly trying to make you something else is the greatest accomplishment.

title: Golden Mean
author: Aristotle
content: Moral excellence comes about as a result of habit. We become just by doing just acts, temperate by doing temperate acts, brave by doing brave acts.

title: Eternal Return
author: Friedrich Nietzsche
content: What if some day or night a demon were to steal into your loneliest loneliness and say to you: This life as you now live it you must live once again and innumerable times again.

title: The Cave Allegory
author: Plato
content: And now, I said, let me show in a figure how far our nature is enlightened or unenlightened. Behold! human beings living in an underground den, which has a mouth open towards the light.

title: Simple Truths
author: Henry David Thoreau
content: The mass of men lead lives of quiet desperation. What is called resignation is confirmed desperation. From the desperate city you go into the desperate country, and have to console yourself with the bravery of minks and muskrats.

title: Human Understanding
author: Michel de Montaigne
content: Man is certainly stark mad; he cannot make a worm, and yet he will be making gods by dozens. We are all patchwork, and so shapeless and diverse in composition that each bit, each moment, plays its own game.

title: Nature's Lessons
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
content: Nature is not fixed but fluid. Spirit alters, moulds, makes it. The immobility or bruteness of nature is the absence of spirit; to pure spirit it is fluid, it is volatile, it is obedient.

title: God is Dead
author: Friedrich Nietzsche
content: God is dead. God remains dead. And we have killed him. How shall we comfort ourselves, the murderers of all murderers? What was holiest and mightiest of all that the world has yet owned has bled to death under our knives.

title: Philosopher King
author: Plato
content: Until philosophers are kings, or the kings and princes of this world have the spirit and power of philosophy, and political greatness and wisdom meet in one, and those commoner natures who pursue either to the exclusion of the other are compelled to stand aside, cities will never have rest from their evils.

title: Human Flourishing
author: Aristotle
content: Happiness is not a feeling but a way of being. Happiness is the meaning and the purpose of life, the whole aim and end of human existence. It consists in activity of soul in accordance with virtue, and if there are more than one virtue, in accordance with the best and most complete.

title: Conformity's Danger
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
content: A foolish consistency is the hobgoblin of little minds, adored by little statesmen and philosophers and divines. With consistency a great soul has simply nothing to do. He may as well concern himself with his shadow on the wall. Speak what you think now in hard words, and to-morrow speak what to-morrow thinks in hard words again, though it contradict every thing you said to-day.

title: Life's Meaning
author: Michel de Montaigne
content: The value of life lies not in the length of days, but in the use we make of them; a man may live long yet live very little. Whether you find satisfaction in life depends not on your tale of years, but on your will. I have lived long enough; my life has been full and complete. Others may write the sequel, for that part belongs to fortune, not to me. Death finds me prepared.
